Title: Material and Energy Balances I
Description: Covers elementary principles of chemical engineering, use of stoichiometry and material and energy balances to analyze chemical processing operations, and application to specific commercial processes.
Prerequisites: CHEM 102 [Min Grade: D] and MATH 122 [Min Grade: D]

Title: Material and Energy Balances II
Description: Covers application of material and energy balances to analyze chemical processing operations, with application to both small-scale and commercial processes. Emphasis is on simultaneous solution of material and energy balances and on time-dependent analysis.
Prerequisites: CHE 211 [Min Grade: D] and CHE 220 [Min Grade: D]

Title: Computational Methods in Chemical Engineering I
Description: Introduces computational approaches and software applied to solve problems in chemical engineering. Software includes spreadsheet programs (Excel), high level computing languages (MATLAB), and chemical process simulation tools (Aspen, HYSYS).
Prerequisites: ENGR 131 [Min Grade: D] or ENGR 132 [Min Grade: D]

Title: Chemical Engineering Thermodynamics I
Description: First and second laws of thermodynamics, use of state functions to solve macroscopic problems, distinction between solving ideal gas and real fluid problems. An introduction to phase equilibrium and mixtures. Concepts of fugacity and activity as measures of nonideality.
Prerequisites: MATH 200 [Min Grade: D] and CHE 211 [Min Grade: D] and CHE 220 [Min Grade: D]

Title: Process Mass Transfer
Description: Covers, within the context of processes previously introduced, mass transfer in mixtures; diffusion, convection, and continuation of transport phenomena; component separation in continuous contractors; gas absorption; liquid-liquid extraction; and simultaneous heat and mass transfer.
Prerequisites: CHE 303 [Min Grade: D] and (CHE 201 [Min Grade: D] or CHE 211 [Min Grade: D]) and (CHE 202 [Min Grade: D] or CHE 212 [Min Grade: D])

Title: Process Modeling II
Description: Covers mathematical modeling of chemical and biochemical processes such as chemical and biochemical reactors and heating and cooling systems, analytical methods for solving algebraic and ordinary-differential equations.
Prerequisites: CHE 305 [Min Grade: D] and CHE 307 [Min Grade: D]

Title: Computational Methods in Chemical Engineering II
Description: This course introduces computational approaches and software applied to solve problems in chemical engineering. The course includes finite element software for solving differential equations (COMSOL Multiphysics) and computer programming.
Prerequisites: CHE 341 [Min Grade: D] and CHE 220 [Min Grade: D]

Title: Chemical Engineering Thermodynamics II
Description: Covers mixture thermodynamics, multi-component, multi-phase equilibrium calculations, and chemical equilibrium calculations for real fluids.
Prerequisites: CHE 230 [Min Grade: D]

Title: Separation Processes
Description: Covers application of thermodynamics and equilibrium stage concepts to separation unit operations in chemical processing.
Prerequisites: CHE 330 [Min Grade: D] and CHE 343 [Min Grade: D]

Title: Fluid Mechanics
Description: Introduces, within the context of processes, transport phenomena, fluid flow, momentum transport, skin friction, drag, and piping networks.
Prerequisites: CHE 212 [Min Grade: D] and CHE 230 [Min Grade: D] and MATH 210 [Min Grade: D]

Title: Heat Transfer
Description: Covers, as a continuation of transport phenomena and within the context of processes, transfer of energy by conduction, convection, and radiation and design of heat exchangers.
Prerequisites: CHE 341 [Min Grade: D]

Title: Mass Transfer
Description: Covers, within the context of processes previously introduced, mass transfer in mixtures; diffusion, convection, and continuation of transport phenomena; component separation in continuous contactors; gas absorption; liquid-liquid extraction; and simultaneous heat and mass transfer.
Prerequisites: CHE 341 [Min Grade: D]

Title: Transport Phenomena in Bioengineering Processes
Description: Covers gas-liquid mass transfer in microbial systems, mass transfer in cells and biofilms, membrane transport, fluid mechanics of fermentation broth, power consumption in agitated vessels, heat transfer, and scale-up of mass transfer equipment.
Prerequisites: (CHE 343 [Min Grade: D] or CHE 304 [Min Grade: D]) and (CHE 341 [Min Grade: D] or CHE 302 [Min Grade: D])

Title: Statistics and Design of Experiments
Description: Provides statistical treatment of engineering data including application of statistical techniques to process model formulation, statistical designs of engineering experiments, and analysis of probabilistic systems.
Prerequisites: MATH 210 [Min Grade: D] or ENGR 232 [Min Grade: D] or MATH 262 [Min Grade: D]

Title: Chemical Engineering Laboratory I
Description: Offers laboratory experience in chemical engineering processes, requiring both experimental design and analysis.
Prerequisites: CHE 341 [Min Grade: D] and CHE 330 [Min Grade: D]

Title: Chemical Engineering Laboratory II
Description: Offers laboratory experience in chemical engineering processes, requiring both experimental design and analysis.
Prerequisites: CHE 343 [Min Grade: D] and CHE 331 [Min Grade: D]

Title: BioProcess Principles
Description: This course is concerned with manufacturing processes involving biological substances. Students gain detailed knowledge in the design and operation of bioreactors and learn about biomolecules produces therein. Specific topics covered include: Cells (type, organization, function and growth); Protein and Enzymes; Bioreactor Process Principles (active vs. passive immobilization, fermentation and scale-up, recovery and purification); Special consideration for animal and plant cell cultures.
Prerequisites: CHE 211 [Min Grade: D] or CHE 201 [Min Grade: D]

Title: Chemical Kinetics and Reactor Design
Description: Covers isothermal and non-isothermal reactor design, series and parallel reactions, and heterogeneous catalysis.
Prerequisites: CHE 330 [Min Grade: D] and CHE 342 [Min Grade: D] and CHE 343 [Min Grade: D]

Title: Bioprocess Unit Operations
Description: Covers separation processes applicable to bio-systems, including liquid-liquid extractions, membrane separations, chromatographic separations, filtration, and centrifugation.
Prerequisites: CHE 305 [Min Grade: D] or CHE 331 [Min Grade: D]

Title: Engineering Economics and Professional Practice
Description: Provides techniques for making engineering project decisions. Topics include the time value of money, key decision criteria, risk analysis, and ethical considerations and consequences of business decisions.
Prerequisites: CHE 211 [Min Grade: D] and CHE 220 [Min Grade: D]

Title: Integrated Case Studies in Chemical Engineering
Description: This course reviews selected cases (market, processes, equipment sets and incidents) from chemical engineering practice whose analysis requires integration of concepts from previous Chemical Engineering courses such as mass and energy transport, thermodynamics, separations and reaction engineering.
Prerequisites: CHE 342 [Min Grade: D] and CHE 343 [Min Grade: D]

Title: The Brewing Process
Description: This course will focus on the critical process steps which make up the brewing process on any scale with special attention to the chemistry and biochemistry of the involved process steps. The lecture material includes the brewing process steps from raw materials to fill/finish including: raw materials, malting, mashing, lautering, boiling, hopping, fermentation, clarification (filtration/centrifugation/flocculation), and fill/finish, as well as a discussion of the fundamentals, impurities chemistry, health concerns and practical knowledge.
Prerequisites: CHEM 242 [Min Grade: D]

Title: Solutions to Climate Change
Description: Climate change will likely be the most important challenge of our time. Drawdown is the theoretical point in the future when greenhouse gas concentrations in the atmosphere peak and then begin to decline, reversing the trend of global warming. Can we get there? How? We will examine the potential impacts of dozens of top solutions to understand where our actions have the most leverage. Solutions range from technical (green energy, buildings, and transportation) to non-technical (food choices and education). The best solutions not only mitigate global warming but also lead to economic benefits and a more just and equitable society.
Prerequisites: Null

Title: Process Systems Engineering
Description: Covers the application of automatic control theory to chemical processes within the context of processes previously introduced.
Prerequisites: (CHE 201 [Min Grade: D] or CHE 211 [Min Grade: D]) and (CHE 202 [Min Grade: D] or CHE 212 [Min Grade: D]) and CHE 303 [Min Grade: D]

Title: Chemical Kinetics and Reactor Design
Description: Covers isothermal and non-isothermal reactor design, series and parallel reactions, and heterogeneous catalysis.
Prerequisites: CHE 304 [Min Grade: D] and (CHE 201 [Min Grade: D] or CHE 211 [Min Grade: D]) and (CHE 202 [Min Grade: D] or CHE 212 [Min Grade: D])

Title: Introduction to Sustainable Engineering
Description: This course introduces students to sustainability in an engineering context. Sustainable engineering encompasses the relationships between technology, society, the environment, and economic prosperity. A variety of systematic approaches will be used for multivariable design and analysis of the sustainability of engineering systems.
Prerequisites: Null

Title: Fundamentals of Solar Cells
Description: This course focuses on the fundamentals of solar cells. It will cover semiconductor materials, basic semiconductor physics, optical and electronic phenomena, and case studies of crystalline silicon, thin film, and nanostructured photovoltaics.
Prerequisites: MATH 200 [Min Grade: D] and CHEM 102 [Min Grade: D] and PHYS 102 [Min Grade: D]

Title: Electrochemical Engineering
Description: This course introduces principles and application of electrochemical equilibria, kinetics, and transport processes.
Prerequisites: CHE 330 [Min Grade: D] and CHE 343 [Min Grade: D]

Title: Introduction to Rheology
Description: Introduces the concepts of how science defines and conceptualizes the behavior of “real” fluids. Covers concepts such as how to characterize, quantify, and simulate non-Newtonian behavior in real fluids.
Prerequisites: CHE 341 [Min Grade: D] or CHE 302 [Min Grade: D]

Title: Safety Engineering
Description: Covers selected topics such as safeguarding systems, fault trees, risk analysis, explosions, fires, and building safety.
Prerequisites: CHE 482 [Min Grade: D]

Title: Polymer Process Technology
Description: Covers chemistry of chain and stepwise polymerization, industrial reactor systems, polymer melt rheology, processing of thermoplastic resins, and plastics properties.
Prerequisites: Null

Title: Chemical Engineering Laboratory III
Description: Offers laboratory experience in chemical engineering processes, requiring both experimental design and analysis.
Prerequisites: CHE 362 [Min Grade: D] (Can be taken Concurrently)

Title: Biochemical Engineering
Description: Introduces underlying biological and engineering principles in an integrate fashion for biopharmaceutical production systems.
Prerequisites: Null

Title: Principles of Colloid Science
Description: This course focuses on fundamental principles of colloid science from a biological perspective. It will cover surface active agents, thermodynamics of self-assembly of surfactants, surface chemistry and physics of monolayers and bilayers, microstructures and phase behavior, specific biological colloids (micelles, liposomes, and lipoproteins), and colloidal stability.
Prerequisites: BIO 141 [Min Grade: C] or BIO 122 [Min Grade: C]

Title: Process Dynamics and Control
Description: Covers the application of automatic control theory to chemical processes within the context of processes.
Prerequisites: MATH 210 [Min Grade: D] and CHE 212 [Min Grade: D]

Title: Chemical Process Safety
Description: Covers selected topics such as safeguarding systems, fault trees, risk analysis, explosions, fires, and process safety.
Prerequisites: CHE 472 [Min Grade: D]

Title: Process Design I
Description: Within the context of previously introduced processes, covers economic feasibility of projects and optimization of equipment and production in the design of process plants.
Prerequisites: CHE 331 [Min Grade: D], CHE 362 [Min Grade: D] (Can be taken Concurrently) and CHE 371 [Min Grade: D] and CHE 372 [Min Grade: D]

Title: Process Design II
Description: Within the context of previously introduced processes, covers execution of feasibility study and preliminary design of process plants.
Prerequisites: CHE 471 [Min Grade: D]

Title: Process Design III
Description: Within the context of previously introduced processes, covers completion of feasibility study and preliminary design of process plants.
Prerequisites: CHE 472 [Min Grade: D]

Title: Process Design I
Description: Within the context of previously introduced processes, covers economic feasibility of projects and optimization of equipment and production in the design of process plants.
Prerequisites: CHE 304 [Min Grade: D] and CHE 308 [Min Grade: D]

Title: Process Design II
Description: Within the context of previously introduced processes, covers execution of feasibility study and preliminary design of process plants. This is a writing intensive course.
Prerequisites: CHE 481 [Min Grade: D]

Title: Process Design III
Description: Within the context of previously introduced processes, covers completion of feasibility study and preliminary design of process plants. This is a writing intensive course.
Prerequisites: CHE 482 [Min Grade: D]

Title: Senior Thesis Research
Description: This course teaches students the ability to structure and write a thesis and defend their research.
Prerequisites: CHE I499 [Min Grade: D]

Title: Independent Study in CHE
Description: Self-directed within the area of study requiring intermittent consultation with a designated instructor.
Repeat Status: Can be repeated multiple times for credit
Prerequisites: Null

Description: Self-directed within the area of study requiring intermittent consultation with a designated instructor.
Repeat Status: Can be repeated multiple times for credit
Prerequisites: Null
